turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Don't use language like that at the dinner table.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Let me go!  Godammit, Frank let go!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Daddy -- stop it!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I didn't know that Andrew was dead until Mr. Sattler called me at home that night.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: We have a witness who saw you go into the house at four thirty.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: What time did you leave?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Six thirty -- and he was very much alive.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Did Marsh use it?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No -- never.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: It had to get there somehow.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: It didn't get there from me.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No, we just had lunch at the hotel with my brother and his new wife. She told me all the dirt. I forgot how interesting things can get around here. It was so good to see them. The last time we visited they were in Europe. He is doing so well. He ordered champagne. For lunch! I nearly died.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I nearly died when we split the bill.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Michael doesn't understand. People who make the kind of money my brother makes don't carry money on them. They keep it all in various accounts.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then we should have had lunch at the bank.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Boy. It sure has been a long time.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We were here two Christmases ago.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Well, that's a long time.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It's not that long.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Well, why don't I just say black so you can say white!  Don't be surprised to find your brother hasn't changed an iota. He hardly ever talks and when he does it's in that tone! You should have heard him at lunch -- not two words until the bill came and then he says, "Worth every penny."

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: SO!

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You said it in that tone! Like you were angry at me, my brother, at the world for forcing you to eat a nice lunch!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Oh Jesus.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I simply can not stand that tone!

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: My Jewish friend's grandmother did.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, no one in my family did! Dad bought cemetery plots at Oak Ridge. One for him, one for mom.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Not to mention people driving over her and doggies doing their business --

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We're not doing it! I'm not even sure it's Christian.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Maybe it's an Italian thing. Their mother was Italian.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Doesn't matter. Move on.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It's a beautiful picture of her.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Why are there two deeds here?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I don't mind waiting.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, there's a lot of boring stuff to do. Lists of people we have to write to. Find mama's relatives addresses in Italy -- stuff like that.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Well, I can help.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I said NO!

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I am so sick and tired of apologizing and not knowing what I've done!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I'm sure you haven't done anything. Have some iced tea. How are the kids?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Eeeww!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I know. I don't understand it either.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: How bizarre!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Mr. Peterson, are you sure mama wrote all this?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Oh, just a old letter from a friend.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No treasure maps, huh?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I do not need instructions from you to bathe!  I knew you'd do this! I knew I'd come all the way here and be shut out as usual! I came to be here for you! I didn't have to come!  Lord knows I was never much welcome in this house before. Apparently dead or alive, nothing's changed.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Aw, Betty.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Carolyn -- you want these candlesticks?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: No. You can have them.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Explain to me again why we didn't do this in Des Moines in an air conditioned office?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Mom's orders.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Lawyer here?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I have some sandwich fixings if you're hungry.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He dropped them off at Betty's mom. Where's Steve?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: He's not coming.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I thought everything WAS arranged.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Well, there's a problem.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What problem?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I remember a Mrs. Delaney but Mama told me years ago she died.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, I don't care if it's legal or not, we're not cremating her and throwing her all over some bridge where we can't even go visit her because she's going to be blown all over the place like an ashtray.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Michael.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Come here a minute.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: "-- going over and over in my mind every detail, every moment of our time together and I ask myself, "What happened to me in Madison County?" I struggle to put it together in a way that allows me to continue knowing we're on separate roads. But then I look through the lens of my camera, and you're there. I start to write an article and I find myself writing it to you. It's clear to me now we have been moving towards each other, towards those four days, all our lives --

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Goddamn sonofabitch! I don't want to hear anymore! Sonofabitch! Burn the damn thing! I don't want to hear it! Throw it away!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What's he saying now?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Well, he just gets on about how if mama ever needed him, she could find him through the National Geographic magazine. He as a photographer. He promises not to write again. Then all it says is...  I love you... Robert.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Robert! Jesus! I'll kill him.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: That would be some trick. He's already dead. That's what this other letter is.  From his attorney. He left most of his things to mama and requested...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: That he be cremated and his ashes thrown on Roseman Bridge.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: DAMN HIM! I knew mama wouldn't have thought of that herself. It was some damn perverted... photographic mind influencing her! When did the bastard die?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Wait a minute! That was thirty years after daddy. Do you think...?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I don't know. I'm completely in the dark here. That's what I get for moving away.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: This happened way before we both got married. I... I can't believe it.  You think she had sex with him?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: My Lord. It must feel real nice living inside your head with Peter Pan and the Easter Bunny.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Don't talk to me like that. She was my mother for Christsakes. And now I find out she was... She was a --!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Don't say that!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, what am I supposed to think?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I can't believe she never told me? We spoke at least once a week. How could she do that?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How did she meet him? Did Dad know? Anything else in that envelope?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: No, I don't think so. I --

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can't believe she's making jokes.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Sshhh. "After going through the safety deposit box, I'm sure you'll find you're way to this letter. It's hard to write this to my own children. I could let this die with the rest of me, I suppose.  But as one gets older, one fears subside. What becomes more and more important is to be known -- known for all that you were during this brief stay. Row said it seems to me to leave this earth without hose you love the most ever really knowing who you were. It's easy for a mother to love her children no matter what -- it's something that just happens. I don't know if it's as simple for children. You're all so busy being angry at us for raising you wrong. But I thought it was important to give you that chance. To give you the opportunity to love me for all that I was..."

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Grateful!?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: "... It's all there in the three notebooks. Read them in order. If you don't want to, I suppose that's okay too. But in that case I want you to know something -- I never stopped loving your father. He was a very good man. It's just that my love for Robert was different. He brought out something in me no one had ever brought out before, or since. He made me feel like a woman in a way few women, maybe more, ever experience..."

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: That's it!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: This is crazy. She waits till she's dead to tell us all this. Well, I got news for you. She was my mother. That's enough for me. I don't have to know who she was.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Well, I'd like to read them.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No. We're going to lock this up and --

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: STOP IT!  I want to read them! If you don't want to, then just leave. But don't you push me around like I'm some mule you paid for -- I already GOT A HUSBAND!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He's getting her drunk. That's what happened. Jesus, maybe he forced himself. That's why she couldn't tell us.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Oh, he did not. He's such a nice guy.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Nice? He's trying to sleep with somebody's wife.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I don't think so. Not yet anyway. And besides, something like that doesn't make you a bad person. He reminds me of Steve in a way. Steve's weak, immoral and a liar but he's still a real nice guy. He just shouldn't be married.  At least not to me. You getting hungry? I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I had no idea it's gotten that bad, sis.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Oh, don't feel sorry for me. Please. No one's forcing me to stay.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then why do you?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: And do what? Live alone? Go back to school? Find someone else? Start a magazine for confused woman? ... What if I can't do any of those things?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Bar across the street.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Have you called Betty?  Maybe you should.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I found out who Lucy Delaney is.  Remember the Delaneys from Hillcrest Road?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Yeah. But I thought she died.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He remarried. Apparently they were having an affair for years. Apparently the first Mrs. Delaney was a bit of a stiff.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: You mean -- she didn't like sex?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I bet mom could've helped her.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Boy. All these years I've resented not living the wild life in some place like Paris and all the time I could've moved back to Iowa... Are you drunk?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Not yet. You want to go?

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I think I better. Between the book and the coffee, I'm this close to raping the busboy.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I used to love this place. I used to take Kathy Reynolds down here.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: You never dated Kathy Reynolds!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Not officially. Her and Steve Kendall were pinned at birth. But I was crazy about her. And for about three months, I managed to catch her during her "exploring" stage.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: I never knew that.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Nobody did.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Was this during Betty?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Everything was during Betty. God we were so young. Why did we think we had to do it all so fast? I've never cheated on Betty. Not once we were married, I mean.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Did we want to?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Only about a thousand times. What do I do now? "What's good enough for mom is good enough for me?"

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: What gets me is I'm 46 years old. I've been in this crummy fucking marriage -

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Carolyn!

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: -- for over twenty years because that's what I was taught -- you stick with it! Normal people don't get divorced. I can't remember the last time my husband made love to me so intensely that he transported me to Europe, for Christ's sake -- quite frankly, I don't think he ever did! And now I find out in between bake sales, my mother was Anais Nin!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What about me! I feel really weird. Like she cheated on me, not dad. Isn't that sick? I don't mean I wanted to sleep with her or anything but -- ya know -- being the only son. You're sort of made to feel like you're the prince of the kingdom, ya know? And in the back of your mind, you kind of think your mother doesn't need sex anymore because she has you.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: You're right -- that is sick.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Mrs. Delaney.  Did you hear the latest?

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: No, what?

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: See. Money don't buy happiness. I must say, she's taking it well.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: I'd kill him. Him and that Redfield woman. Together. First one then the other. And then I'd laugh.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: I'd laugh first then I'd kill them. Make sure they heard me laughing.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: She's changed.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: She used to be so friendly.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: My niece had "the changes" when she was thirty-one.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: No. What a tragedy. What happened?

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: She changed.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: Oh, this heat! Times like this I wish we took that offer from your brother and moved on up to Michigan.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: They got heat in Michigan.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: Not this kind of heat.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Heat is heat.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: Heat is not heat! There's different kinds! And this heat is much hotter than what they got in Michigan. You go and call your brother and see if he don't say the same thing.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I'll get right on it.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Well, nobody put a gun to his head.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: Oh, shut up! It's the woman who's in control of these situations. Men don't know which end is up till a woman points.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: What do you know about "the changes"?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Well, I didn't know they was a secret club.

turns.speaker: ELEANOR
turns.text: Don't talk about what you don't know. Besides, she's too young for "the changes."

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Madge?

turns.speaker: MADGE
turns.text: Hi. I made some brown betty. I sent Floyd off to town with the boy. I said -  "Floyd, I'm going to visit my girlfriend and spend the afternoon and that's all there is to it. He said who's going to make lunch? I said I'm taking a sick day. Eat at the dinner." Isn't that hilarious?  He didn't dare raise an eyebrow -- I don't even want to tell you how late he was out last night with those good for nothings from the Sandford ranch. I am so sorry, honey, I let two days pass before I came by, but with the boy home the time just escapes me. Have you heard from Richard? How's the fair? God, it's hot.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Madge. Please. Something's happened. I've met someone. I've fallen in love in a way I've never thought could happen my entire life. It's our last day together. I feel like I'm going to die when he leaves. Please. Help me.

turns.speaker: MADGE
turns.text: Oh, honey. I'm so sorry. But you've got to be grateful for even feeling the little you've be given. Believe me. Go to him. Don't let him leave without these new precious hours you've got left. And if you need anyone to cry on, you know where I am.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't know. I woke up a little dizzy. I didn't sleep well. I think I need to lay down.

turns.speaker: MADGE
turns.text: You want me to call the doctor?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, no. I just didn't sleep well. I'm not used to sleeping alone. And this heat. Would you mind?

turns.speaker: MADGE
turns.text: No, of course not. I'll just clean up.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, leave it. I'll do it later. Listen, maybe you and Floyd can come for dinner on Saturday. I'm sure Richard'll have so many stories to tell you both about the fair and all.

turns.speaker: MADGE
turns.text: Oh, that'll be nice.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Are you supposed to be in Iowa?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Roseman Bridge?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That's it.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well, you're pretty close. It's only about two miles from here.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh, terrific. Which way?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: If I'm not taking you away from anything.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I was just going to have some iced tea then split the atom, but that can wait.  I just have to get my shoes.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Pretty country.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Hmm-mmm.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: There's a wonderful smell about Iowa -- very particular to this part of the country. Do you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I can't describe it. I think it's from the loam in the soil. This very rich, earthy kind of... alive... No. No, that's not right. Can you smell it?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Maybe it's because I live here.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That must be it. It's a great smell.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Are you from Washington originally?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Uh-huh. Lived there till I was twenty or so and then moved to Chicago when I got married.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh. When did you move back?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: After the divorce.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How long you been married?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Uh... uh...  Umm... long time.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You don't look like a native, if you don't mind my saying so.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, I don't mind. I'm not from here. I was born in Italy.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Well, from Italy to Iowa -- that's a story!  Whereabouts in Italy?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Small town on the Eastern side no one's ever heard of called Bari.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh yeah, Bari. I've been there.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, really?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh, yeah. Actually, I had an assignment in Greece and I had to go through Bari to get the boat at Brindisi. But it looked so pretty I got off and stayed for a few days. Breathtaking country.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You just... got off the train because it looked pretty?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yeah. Excuse me a sec.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: So, how long you've been living here?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Long.  You just got off the train and stayed without knowing anyone there?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: This won't take long. I'm shooting tomorrow morning. I just need to do some prep work.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't mind waiting.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: This time of year.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Would you do me a favor and go to the truck? Inside that leather bag with the pockets is a package of lens cleaners. Would you grab me one?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh there you are.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh! You caught me.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Men sill give women flowers, don't they? I mean, as a sign of appreciation? I'm not that out of date, am I?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, not at all --  except those are poisonous.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: WHAT!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Are you by nature a sadistic person?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, I'm not.  I don't know why I said that. I've been in a very... strange mood all day. I've never done anything like that before. It's... I'm just...  Well, you know, the whole world is just going nuts.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Looking for something in particular? There's not much of a selection.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I found this Chicago station before. Wait a minute...  Here it is.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh, that's nice.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Want another cigarette?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Well, thank you for all your help, Mrs. Johnson.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Francesca.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Francesca. Robert.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Lemon?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Mind if I smoke?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Sure you want to keep those in the house?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I'm so sorry about that. It was rude. I think I just got nervous for some reason.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I thought it was funny.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Where are you staying while you're here?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: A little place with cabins. The something-Motor Inn. I haven't checked in yet.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: And how long are you here for?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: As long as it takes, I might stay a week. No more I don't think. Where's your family?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: My husband took the kids to the Illinos State Fair. My daughter's entering a prize steer.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh. How old?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: About a year and a half.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, your kids.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh. Michael's 17 and Carolyn's 16.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Must be nice having kids.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Everything does. One of the laws of nature. People are always so afraid of change. But if you look at it like it's something you can count on happening, it's actually a comfort. Not many things you can count on for sure.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I guess. Except I'm one of the people it frightens.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I doubt that.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Italy to Iowa? I'd call that a change.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Richard was in the army. I met him while I was living in Naples. I didn't know where Iowa was. I only cared that it was America. And of course, being with Richard.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What's he like?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: He's very... clean.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Clean?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I mean yes, he's clean but he's also other things. He's a very hard worker. Very honest. Very caring. Gentle. Good father.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: And clean.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes. Very clean.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Feeling better?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Much.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Is the dizziness gone?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I better go. You sure you're all right?  It's been a pleasure. Sincerely.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I feel so embarrassed.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Why? You uncorked a bottle. From what I can tell, I got here just in time. Any later and you'd have made the front page, running down Main Street naked, smoking Camels out of your butt.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: But I... We don't even know each other.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You have no reason to feel ashamed. You haven't said anything you don't have a right to. And if anybody tells you different -- you just send them to me.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Would you like to stay for dinner?  There aren't many choices in town and ... anyway, you'd have to eat alone. So would I.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That's very nice of you. I don't get many dinner invitations on the job. It would be a welcome change. Thanks.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Help cook?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Sure. Men cook. We don't all eat bananas with our feet, ya know.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: She starts sniffing me.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh my God...  You're blushing.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: It's still a very sensitive memory for me.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Then what happened?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: We got engaged.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh you!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You ought to write these stories down.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Nah. I've tried. My writing's too technical, I think. Problem of being a journalist too long is you stop giving yourself permission to invent. I better just stick to making pictures.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: "Making pictures." I like that. You really love what you do, don't you?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm kind of obsessed by it, actually.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Why, do you think?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I don't know if obsessions have reasons. I think that's why they're obsessions.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You sound like an artist.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No. I wouldn't say that. National Geographic isn't exactly the hub of artistic inspiration. They like their wild life in focus and without any personal comment. I don't mind really. I'm not artist. I'd faced that a long time ago. It's the course of being well-adjusted. I'm too normal.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't think you're normal.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I didn't mean that the way it sounded.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Well, let's just call it a compliment and move on.  Did you love teaching?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: And did you?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I'd like to think so. I know one of them went on to Medical school.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Why did you stop?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: My children. And Richard didn't like my working.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Do you miss it?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't know. I've never thought about it... what was the most exciting place you've ever been to? Unless you're tired of talking about it.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You're asking a man if he's too tired to talk about himself? You don't get out much, do you?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm sorry. That was...

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. It's all right. I just meant, it might be a little dull for you, telling all this to some housewife in the middle of nowhere.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: This is your home. It's not nowhere. And it's not dull.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: My God. How I'd love to see that.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: They have safaris for tourists now. Maybe you can convince your husband.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well, it's kind of buggy out there.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Have no fear. This Shoshone Medicine Woman taught me how to make bug repellent tea out of tree root.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You drink bug repellent?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, you rub it on you. I have some in the truck. Don't go away.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Smells like dirt.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You get used to it.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You want to go back in?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I'm all right. It's working.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You've got it all right here, you know. It's just as beautiful as any other place I've seen. God, it knocks me out.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: This "... Of what I call God and fools can Nature." Who wrote that?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Umm, I don't know. I can look it up.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'd appreciate it. I like knowing who I'm stealing from. If you can't create art I think the least you can do is recognize it around you, don't you think? There is...  ... so much beauty.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You sure you won't let me help you with those dishes?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I'll do them later.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Francesca?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Francesca?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: We're not doing anything wrong, do you.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Do you mind if I... ask you why you got divorced?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Not at all. I wasn't around much... So why did I get married? Well, I thought it was a good idea at the time. Have a home base. Roots. You can get lost moving around so much.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: So what happened?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I never got lost. For some reason, I'm more at home everywhere than at one place. So I decided I'll think of myself as some kind of world citizen. I belong everywhere and nowhere. I'm kin to everyone, and no one in particular. See, once you get into the habit of not needing anyone, it's kind of hard to break.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You must get lonely at times.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Never touch the stuff. I've got friends all over the world. Good friends I can see when I want, if I want.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Woman friends, too?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm a loner, I'm not a monk.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You really don't need anyone?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, I think I need everyone! I love people. I want to meet them all! I just think there are too many out there saying "This is mine." or "She's mine." Too many lines have been drawn. World's breaking apart because of man's weakness for some testosterone conquests over territory and power and people. He wants control over what deep down he knows he has no control over whatsoever and it scares him silly.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Why doesn't it scare you?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I embrace Mystery. I don't know what's coming. And I don't mind.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Do you ever regret it? The divorce, I mean.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Do you ever regret not having a family?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Not everybody's supposed to have a family.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: But -- how can you just live for what you want? What about other people?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I told you, I love other people.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: But no one in particular.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No. But I love them just the same.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: But it's not the same.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That's not what you're saying. I know it's not the same. What you're saying is, it's not as good. Or it's not as normal or proper.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, I'm just saying --

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm a little sick of this American Family Ethic everyone seems to be hypnotized by in this country. I guess you think I'm just some poor displaced soul doomed to roam the earth without a self-cleaning oven and home movie.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Just because someone chooses to settle down and have a family doesn't necessarily mean they're hypnotized. Just because I've never seen a gazelle stampede doesn't mean I'm asleep in the world.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Do you want to leave your husband?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: My mistake. I apologize.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What made you ask such a question?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I thought that's what we were doing -- asking questions.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I thought we were just having a conversation. You seem to be reading all this meaning into it. Meanings I must be too simple to, uh... interpret or something.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I already apologized.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Listen, I'm sorry I --

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, no. Forgive me. I made a mistake. It was an inappropriate thing to ask.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: ... I feel like something's been spoiled now.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Francesca?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes! Hi.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Am I interrupting anything?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I was just... No.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm sorry I didn't call sooner, but I just read your note. I stuffed it into my pocket. The light was fading and I had to get my shot.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: The light was fading. Huh-huh.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I would love to come for dinner.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Wonderful. Uh...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Listen, I have to shoot Cedar Bridge until a little after sunset. I want a few night shots. Would you like to come with me? If you're interested...

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh, sure. Great.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'll pick you up.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I'll drive myself. I have a few errands. I'll meet you there.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Okay. See you later.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yeah. See you later.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: It's Robert.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh, hi. Look, I'm running a little late, but I'll still...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Listen, don't take this the wrong way but, I'm wondering if this is such a good idea.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I uh... I had lunch in town today. Happened to cross paths with "that Redfield woman." I apologize. I thought you were half-joking about that.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh. I guess you got the whole story.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: The cashier at the general store was very dangerous.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I think he's running for town crier next year.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I now know more about their affair than I remember about my marriage.  Francesca, the last thing I want to do is put you in any kind of situation that would... even though we know it's just -- I mean, it's nothing like that, but if anybody saw us or...

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I understand.  That's very kind of you.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I want you to come.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Sorry I'm late. Richard called.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh, how is he?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Fine. They're all having a good time. How many more shots do you have?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Couple. Want to help?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Can I help?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Actually, no. I've got everything under control. I'd like to clean up myself a bit. I'm going to take a bath. Dinner'll be ready in about a half hour.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How about if I set the table?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Would you like a beer for your bath?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes, that'd be nice.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Are you comfortable?  Do you... want to move to the bedroom?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. I can't. Not yet.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You want to eat something?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Take me somewhere.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Right now. Tell me someplace you've been -- someplace on the other side of the world. Anywhere but here.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How about Italy?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How about Bari?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes. Tell me about the day you got off the train.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Have you ever been to that station?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You know that little place nearby with the striped awning that sells sandwiches and little pizzas...

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: It's okay. It's not that hot anymore. Thanks God.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I just feel like I'm getting a little ... out of control that's all. It's kind of frightening.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Why!? Because, I'm having thoughts I hardly know what to do with. I... can't seem to... stop them.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Nobody's asking you to.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: And arraccinos and zeppolis. Yes! I know it!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I sat outside and had coffee.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Where? Near the doorway or the near the front of the church?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Near the church.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I sat there once. It was hot. Like today. I'd been shopping. I had all these bags around my feet I kept having to move every time the waiter came by...

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: On that one is beautiful. Look at their expressions. As if the camera weren't on them at all. As if they had no strength left to hide what they were feeling.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: He's a genius. They're not photographs -- they're stories, entire histories captured in moments.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I bet you could do a book.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No. I couldn't.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Why do you say that?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Because I already tried once.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: But you don't mind.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, I don't mind.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What were you like when you were younger?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Trouble. Why?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I just wondered. Why were you trouble?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I had a temper.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What were your parents like?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I can't do this, honey.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Try and live a lifetime before Friday. Cram it all in.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You're somewhere else, where?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Just that it's been a perfect day and that I'd like to skip my fancy dessert and go home after this.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Uh-huh. And?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You're right, you know. We don't have much time.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Where was she?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Across the street. She went into the park and got turned around and didn't know her way out.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I don't know why I'm so tired all of a sudden.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Long day. Go to sleep.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Am I too heavy for you?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No.
